text:
hey everyone welcome to Pai's kitchen today 
we're going to travel to Indonesia and make

one of the classic dishes nasi goreng and that 
just literally means fried rice now the first

time I had Indonesian food I fell in love 
with the flavors instantly and I think it's

because Indonesian cuisine uses a lot of the same 
ingredients as Thai cuisine so the flavors were

just super familiar to me as I'm super excited 
to be doing one of their dishes on Pai's kitchen

today so let's get started so we're gonna start 
by making herb paste it's the base of the fried

rice so some garlic into the my mortar and pestle 
here and also shallots so thinly sliced shallots

and shallots as I found out is used a lot in 
Indonesian cuisine as it is in tyfa's in shrimp

paste so this is shrimp paste now I've used shrimp 
paste before on hot Thai kitchen but the shrimp

paste that I'm using today is Malaysian shrimp 
paste which is closer to indonesian shrimp paste

and Thai soup paces so it comes in a block like 
this Thai shrimp paste is usually not as hard and

it comes in a tub however they're more or less 
the same so if you have tight shrimp paste you

don't need to go and get another one like this 
I just wanted to show you and then the package

this is the one that I have it's called Villa 
connoting that's in Malay in Indonesian it'll

be called porosity and in Thai it's cafeé they 
smell the same I tasted this straight up and it

tastes a little bit different but really doesn't 
matter so minor so I'm gonna pound this up into

a paste just like that is fine just a rough paste 
it doesn't need to be liquefied or superfine okay

let's make the sauce which I love the sauce 
because it's so quick and easy I have got here

some sweet soy sauce so this is Indonesian sweet 
soy sauce it's called ketchup monies if you have

a Thai sweet soy sauce I haven't tasted them side 
by side but I'm gonna guess that you can use that

as well it's very thick very sweet it's got an 
intensive molasses flavor to it and then fish

sauce so when I went to culinary school I had a 
friend who's from Indonesia and she kept saying

sweet soy sauce the only thing sweet soy sauce the 
most important thing Indonesian cookie and so I

haven't met I haven't seen over years but the one 
thing I do remember about her is how passionate

she was about sweet soy sauce and I'm also going 
to add some spicy some sambal and this is just

ground-up chili and vinegar I'm going to put quite 
a bit here because I don't think it's very spicy

alright so that's it that's the sauce super-easy 
now one quick thing before we get cooking protein

as I said nasi goreng just means fried rice which 
means you can put anything in it that you want and

typically as I understand it people just use this 
as a way to use up leftover so leftover meat is

perfect for putting in your nasi goreng and just 
whatever n-bit the vegetables you've got in your

fridge right so I've got here just some shredded 
chicken that I have left over from another dinner

you don't have to put any protein and if you want 
and that's it I think we're ready to cook okay so

I've got a wok here with a little bit of oil in 
it and oh by the way when you weren't looking I

went and fried a sunny-side up egg and I'm pretty 
sure I don't need to show you that but fYI there's

the sunny side of it that we're gonna put on top 
at the end okay so in here I'm going to add my

herb paste right away mmm shrimp paste in the air 
if you haven't worked with shrimp paste before it

might be a little pungent okay but this is only a 
little bit and I did tell you it's optional right

you don't have to put the shrimp paste but I 
think it really adds a nice umami flavor and

then if you're putting vegetables or meats now's 
the time to add it okay but if you're not putting

any vegetables or meats then skip this cut so 
once our chicken is heated up I'm going to go

in with the rice which is cold so it's easier 
for me to break that break it apart and by the

way you can put the egg in the rice as opposed 
to frying it separately if you want I just like

fried eggs okay now all the sauce goes in and 
then I'm also going to add just a little bit

of salt because the sweet soy sauce isn't that 
salty so right now we only have the fish sauce

of salty and the shrimp paste mmm that looks 
good already and now you just getting the rice

to be thoroughly coated in the sauce and you can 
go ahead and crank the heat all the way so you

want to dry it out get even a little toastiness 
going if you can that is it for the fried rice

I'm going to turn it off and I'm gonna put in 
some green onions for a little greenery now I

know it doesn't look like much right now it's just 
like fried rice with chicken but we're gonna deck

the plate with more fixin so let's do that by the 
way you might want to make sure you've got good

ventilation when you fry this at home otherwise 
you're sure your house is going to smell like

shrimp paste for a few days now let's look at 
all the fixin's that are sort of the classic

accompaniments to nasi goreng and so these are 
the ones that my Indonesian friend suggested

to me if you have your preferences please let 
me know in the comments what you like to put

on your nasi goreng please I would love to know 
so the first thing the most important thing in

my opinion is shrimp crackers these are called 
Group book so I'll show you what the package

looks like in a second they're delicious we had 
them in Thailand as well but we never put them

on fried rice which is a brilliant idea they come 
in a package like this okay and they're made from

shrimp and tapioca starch and I love this brand 
this is a great bread that has a lot of shrimp

sometimes especially the non Indonesian kind of 
like all starch and no Sherman those aren't very

good they taste like styrofoam and then all you 
do is heat the oil so it's quite hot 350 is okay

you drop these in and slowly those sort of unfurl 
themselves and they'll become crispy and slightly

golden brown in just seconds and that's it you 
take them out they're delicious you can keep

them in an airtight container for quite a while 
as we have it now it's primarily salty and sweet

we need something tart and in Thailand we use 
lime but in Indonesia they like to put pickle

so this is a really simple cucumber and carrot 
pickles I will include the recipe in the written

portion on the website and of course you can just 
use whatever pickles you've got sunny-side up eggs

just put that right on top that looks great 
one last thing I'm going to put on here is my

absolute favorite it's fried shallots I have used 
spiced shallots in many of my videos we use them

in Thailand too and they're quite easy to make 
so I'll include how to make them in the written

recipe and all so link to another video that 
will show you how you can make these butts very

simple you basically fry them on low heat until 
they're golden and you can buy fried shallots

like already fried at Asian grocery stores but 
I find they're not very fresh like they've been

fried God knows how long and the flavor is 
just not as good a little more sprinkling of

green onions can't forget freshness some tomatoes 
cucumber would be great with this - you know cuz

you need something you know refreshing on this 
plate look at that doesn't that look fun it's

almost hard to know where to begin there's so much 
good stuff going on well I'm going in with the egg

gotta get some fried shallots on there for 
sure it's kind of hard to describe it that

flavor of the sweet soy sauce is intense it's 
a little smoky so it gives this flavor to the

rice that we don't have in Thai fried rice which 
is why I love this so much is something totally

different oh my god and I got it going with 
the pickles to cleanse my fat with the rice

that's rich the eggs creamy crunchy crippled 
and tart pickles you can keep going all day I

mean it's just so much fun so if you make 
nasty coding at home I would love to know

what you like to put in your nasty coding 
you can put that down in the comments and

the recipe for my version will be on hot Thai 
Kitchen comm and when you make it don't forget

to send me a photo on Facebook Twitter 
or Instagram and subscribe right here if

you haven't done so and I will see you next 
time for your next delicious and edit sugar
